codes.name: AI Adoption and Integration at RAND
codes.description: This code captures discussions about the current state, challenges, and strategies for adopting and integrating AI tools and practices within the RAND Corporation. It includes observations on the pace of adoption, internal tool quality, and the need for organizational initiatives.
codes.semantic_definition: Any mention of RAND's internal use of AI, its policies, the quality of RAND-specific AI tools (e.g., RANDChat), or the overall organizational approach to AI.
example_quotes: My sense is the Army thinks our competitors are integrating AI wholistically. Secretary of the Army wants Palantir and not RAND. So how do we make sure we don’t get put out of business in that environment.
Most ppl I ask, at RAND there are not as many ppl using it; the few that have say they use it to do what I am doing to help fix code or wordsmith text.
I've used ranch at a few times and it just hasn't been as good as just using Chachi PT.

codes.name: RANDChat Quality and Usage
codes.description: This code captures specific feedback and experiences related to RAND's internal AI tool, RANDChat, including its perceived quality, limitations compared to external LLMs, and its current applications by researchers.
codes.semantic_definition: Direct comments on RANDChat's performance, its comparison to other LLMs (e.g., ChatGPT, Claude), or specific instances of its use or non-use due to quality concerns.
example_quotes: I've used ranch at a few times and it just hasn't been as good as just using Chachi PT.

The RAND one I used early on and used it to do tedious things and playing with code and I found someone else’s code and asked can you convert this R code to Stata code and kept playing with it and learned what is good and not good.

I think the RAND CHAT one is not as good, a couple of times I would ask RAND CHAT, are there systematic studies on blah or what do you know about x and y and it would give me papers/citations that were not real. So I always check.

codes.name: Pace of AI Adoption
codes.description: This code reflects observations and opinions on how quickly or slowly AI tools are being adopted and integrated across RAND, including comparisons to external organizations or the broader research community.
codes.semantic_definition: Statements about RAND being 'behind the curve,' 'slower,' or the general rate at which researchers are starting to use AI tools.
example_quotes: Most ppl I ask, at RAND there are not as many ppl using it; the few that have say they use it to do what I am doing to help fix code or wordsmith text.
I think based on the professional conference I went to, I think we might be a little bit slower [level of adoption], whether that is right I don’t know.

The way AI adoption happens is stovepipped and a lot of the discussion is in GER, so in QA process, I will like, if someone utilized RANDCHAT (to write their report) to make sure that is not happening.

codes.name: Need for Training and Guidance
codes.description: This code captures suggestions and requests for more structured education, use case examples, and best practices to facilitate the safe and effective adoption of AI tools within RAND.
codes.semantic_definition: Any mention of the need for seminars, workshops, illustrated guides, or sharing sessions to help researchers understand and apply AI.
example_quotes: Need to be company wide ai initiatives that every unit and division are asked to participate in.

It would be for folks to have sort of illustrated use case guides for, OK. Let's say you wanna use large language models to do X. Here's some literal examples of how this is used and how this fit into an actual project lifecycle and turned into an actual product that was published...

There could be more along those lines, showcasing how ppl use it successfully. A little bit but not a ton and someone super savvy and using it a lot could give a rundown of how they use it day to day.

codes.name: AI Benefits and Opportunities
codes.description: This code encompasses discussions about the positive impacts, efficiencies, and new possibilities that AI tools offer for research, project management, and general workflow. It highlights areas where AI can save time, improve quality, or enable new types of analysis.
codes.semantic_definition: Any statement describing a positive application, efficiency gain, or new capability enabled by AI, such as time savings, improved code, better summarization, or enhanced project management.
example_quotes: We can use AI for a literature review that would have taken a RA 20 days so benefits of cost savings but I worry about career development and skillset development among the younger folks.

I found AI very helpful in tracking in tracing it back to the interview. So when you have a very good quote, you usually remember where it is, but when it's. Something that is not as like eye-catching, but very important to include. It's kind of helpful in organizing the notes in a way that it's very, very easy. To trace back to the interview to the specific moment of a point in your data set that you can easily recite and create these citations for you.

AI has been really helpful with writing like any type of code I write primarily in Python, and I mentioned right? I'm a new hire, so I joined a project, you know, trying to make a good first impression here at Rand. And they're like, oh, Caroline, you know, P. Like can you do this? And I had no idea how to do this, but I was like, well, I know how to read Python code. I don't know how to, you know, write this from scratch, necessarily. But you know, I used to get me a good start, you know, kind of figure out how to write it.

codes.name: Efficiency and Time Savings
codes.description: This code highlights instances where AI tools significantly reduce the time or effort required for various research and administrative tasks, leading to increased productivity.
codes.semantic_definition: Direct statements about AI saving time, making processes faster, or reducing labor hours for tasks like literature reviews, data processing, or writing.
example_quotes: We can use AI for a literature review that would have taken a RA 20 days so benefits of cost savings...
AI has been really helpful with writing like any type of code I write primarily in Python... it just helped me write code like so much faster.
Summaries I found AI super helpful and that's probably was one of the. 1st. Objectives of first use cases to summarize stuff, and it's been super helpful saving a lot of time.

codes.name: Code Generation and Debugging
codes.description: This code focuses on the utility of AI for assisting with writing, optimizing, and debugging computer code used in quantitative analysis or data processing.
codes.semantic_definition: Mentions of AI helping to write code, fix errors in code, convert code between languages (e.g., R to Stata), or make code more concise.
example_quotes: I have used AI tools to help with my code. I know in general how to execute one of these methods but sometime there are new packages written but my code is having errors so I can take the code and put it in an LLM; can you fix this error or can you write this more concisely?
AI has been really helpful with writing like any type of code I write primarily in Python... it just helped me write code like so much faster.
I just can copy all over in and tell it. Please find where my syntax is wrong, but also ask in which tool is the best...

codes.name: Text Summarization and Rewriting
codes.description: This code captures the use of AI for condensing long texts, generating executive summaries, or rephrasing content for clarity, brevity, or specific audiences.
codes.semantic_definition: Applications of AI to summarize reports, articles, meeting minutes, or to rewrite text for different purposes (e.g., 'explain like I'm 5,' shortening).
example_quotes: My husband was using Claude and told me it is good at writing things. So can it tell me if this is a valid design. Also, sometimes to re-write or shorten things but not exactly causal inference but to make things shorter. I would take “Reddit explain like I’m 5”.
I take the whole proposal and say write an executive summary; it is great at doing that; you can’t trust it but sometimes stuff that is off and misses nuance but it is pretty good at that.
Summaries I found AI super helpful and that's probably was one of the. 1st. Objectives of first use cases to summarize stuff, and it's been super helpful saving a lot of time.

codes.name: Project Management Assistance
codes.description: This code includes ideas and examples of how AI could streamline project management tasks, such as generating meeting minutes, tracking action items, or optimizing project timelines.
codes.semantic_definition: Suggestions or uses of AI for administrative or organizational tasks related to project execution, like automating meeting notes, identifying critical paths, or labor forecasting.
example_quotes: It's a really silly example, but meeting minutes like just having AI transcribed the meeting minutes put it in like here are the key decisions. Here are the action items.

If there were a way to more fully automate that process of the editing, the proofreading everything else were, you know. Dramatically more rapid than they are right now. I I think that right that would feedback I think into literally how I conceptualized the opportunities for research projects.
I said I thought it was odd we don’t use some of the internal budgeting and figuring out where ppl have labor allocated to do labor forecasting.

codes.name: AI Challenges and Risks
codes.description: This code covers concerns, limitations, and potential negative consequences associated with the use or implementation of AI. It includes issues related to data quality, ethical considerations, job displacement, and competitive disadvantages.
codes.semantic_definition: Any mention of problems, difficulties, ethical dilemmas, or potential harms arising from AI use, such as job loss, intellectual property concerns, data mining, hallucinations, or security risks.
example_quotes: The risk is that we will end up utilizing AI for stuff our junior folks used to do. We can use AI for a literature review that would have taken a RA 20 days so benefits of cost savings but I worry about career development and skillset development among the younger folks.
One of the things researchers are increasingly concerned about is data mining, which is going into a data set and just, you know, looking at all these different options.

I don’t want to inadvertently take someone else’s intellectual property. Saw a thing on john Oliver, ppl making images, based on what is in the public and making something new so it is kind of stealing.

codes.name: Job Displacement and Skill Erosion
codes.description: This code captures concerns about AI automating tasks traditionally performed by junior staff, potentially leading to job loss or hindering the development of critical skills among younger researchers.
codes.semantic_definition: Worries about AI replacing human roles, particularly for entry-level positions, or preventing the acquisition of essential research skills.
example_quotes: The risk is that we will end up utilizing AI for stuff our junior folks used to do... I worry about career development and skillset development among the younger folks.

codes.name: Competitive Risk for RAND
codes.description: This code addresses the concern that if RAND does not effectively adopt AI, it could lose its competitive edge against other organizations (e.g., private AI companies) that are more aggressively integrating AI into their operations.
codes.semantic_definition: Statements about RAND's need to maintain a competitive advantage, the risk of being 'put out of business' by AI companies, or the perception that clients might prefer AI-driven solutions from competitors.
example_quotes: My sense is the Army thinks our competitors are integrating AI wholistically. Secretary of the Army wants Palantir and not RAND. Palantir would be doing things on our data. So we think there is a risk to our research being utilized opportunistically by AI company to get ahead and to put us out of business. How do we maintain a competitive edge.

codes.name: Data Privacy and Intellectual Property
codes.description: This code covers concerns about the security of sensitive data when used with AI tools, and the risk of inadvertently infringing on intellectual property rights when AI generates content.
codes.semantic_definition: Worries about sensitive data being exposed to external LLMs, or AI-generated text/images potentially plagiarizing or 'stealing' existing intellectual property.
example_quotes: I don’t want to inadvertently take someone else’s intellectual property. Saw a thing on john Oliver, ppl making images, based on what is in the public and making something new so it is kind of stealing.
I would just copy you know, all of my code and put it into a large language model and say hey, this is the. Problem I'm having help me fix it but I'm not gonna do that if it has sensitive data right?

codes.name: AI Accuracy and Reliability
codes.description: This code addresses issues related to the trustworthiness of AI-generated content, including the potential for 'hallucinations' (false information) and the need for human verification.
codes.semantic_definition: Mentions of AI producing incorrect information, making up citations, or the necessity to 'check' AI outputs for accuracy.
example_quotes: I think the RAND CHAT one is not as good, a couple of times I would ask RAND CHAT, are there systematic studies on blah or what do you know about x and y and it would give me papers/citations that were not real. So I always check.
Especially hallucinations. I know a lot of researchers are pretty freaked out about. You know, given the sort of reputational risks involved in that kind of thing.
you can’t trust it but sometimes stuff that is off and misses nuance but it is pretty good at that.

codes.name: Ethical and Methodological Pitfalls
codes.description: This code covers broader ethical and methodological concerns, such as data mining, overfitting statistical models, and the need for Institutional Review Board (IRB) guidance for AI applications involving human subjects.
codes.semantic_definition: Discussions about the risks of 'data mining,' 'overfitting,' or the need for ethical review processes (like IRB/HSPC) to adapt to AI use in research.
example_quotes: One of the things researchers are increasingly concerned about is data mining, which is going into a data set and just, you know, looking at all these different options.

I would hope that kind of any quant researcher right is familiar with the concept of overfitting. And I guess this speaks to the risk. Is that like people who maybe are not familiar with these ideas, right? Are trying to explore AI in this way.
working with our hspc, the IRB Institutional Review Board, since I'm assuming most all these projects, especially if they involve real people, we'll have to have some type of clearance.

codes.name: Research Methods and AI Impact
codes.description: This code focuses on the various research methods discussed in the interviews and how AI currently impacts or could potentially impact their execution, efficiency, and quality. It includes both qualitative and quantitative approaches.
codes.semantic_definition: Any discussion of specific research methodologies (e.g., interviews, surveys, modeling, statistical analysis, causal inference) and how AI tools are or could be applied to them, or how AI changes the nature of these methods.
example_quotes: Interview coding, something way better than Dedoose. We do a lot of interviews and the coding is uneven in quality. So it would be great if we had some standard way to do that and a tool to help with that.

I think that the data I think almost every project has to do descriptive right, provide sort of what is the description of the data. So that's a common thing across any project. I think they all have to deal with missing data and how are you gonna address missing or lost a follow up data. Those are things that I think could be automated in some way.
I've also done things for proposal writing and taken my idea where I want to use a particular design and poke holes in this; What are the problems with this; how can I strengthen this?

codes.name: Qualitative Methods and AI
codes.description: This code focuses on the application of AI to qualitative research methods, including interview coding, theme extraction, and the challenges of designing effective qualitative protocols.
codes.semantic_definition: Any discussion of AI's role in interviews, focus groups, case studies, or other qualitative data analysis, particularly for tasks like coding, theme identification, or question development.
example_quotes: Interview coding, something way better than Dedoose. We do a lot of interviews and the coding is uneven in quality. So it would be great if we had some standard way to do that and a tool to help with that.
But in terms of the being able to analyse the data and to and to pull out themes. That seems very straightforward and something that AI could.
It's qualitative coding, but like adding a layer so that AI remembers, remembers and gives you an output which traces back to the original interviews.

codes.name: Quantitative Methods and AI
codes.description: This code covers the use of AI in quantitative research, including data collection, cleaning, variable creation, statistical analysis, and the challenges associated with these processes.
codes.semantic_definition: Any discussion of AI's role in statistical analysis, modeling, surveys, data management (e.g., creating data dictionaries, handling missing data), or causal inference.
example_quotes: I think that the data I think almost every project has to do descriptive right, provide sort of what is the description of the data... I think they all have to deal with missing data and how are you gonna address missing or lost a follow up data. Those are things that I think could be automated in some way.

So we want to come up with a rubric for what? How we're going to characterize those policies and then have the machine go through and extract the relevant text statements or, you know, other information. Maybe it's data from tables so that we can then create these policy variables that go into. Models.

The time-consuming process of pulling data down, checking code. So one thing when I feed it in and there is an error, but then you can use the ai tools to check the code, annotate the code, replicability those are time consuming and for AI.

codes.name: Literature Review and Environmental Scans
codes.description: This code specifically addresses the application of AI to conduct literature reviews, synthesize information from numerous papers, and perform environmental scans to identify relevant research or policy documents.
codes.semantic_definition: Uses of AI to sift through large volumes of text (e.g., research papers, policy documents) to extract summaries, answer specific questions, or filter relevant content.
example_quotes: We can use AI for a literature review that would have taken a RA 20 days so benefits of cost savings...

we did write a python script to use the RAND CHAT to review a bunch of papers. So we did the literature review and had it spit out in a spreadsheet a once sentence summary of the paper or we asked it questions, is this paper based in the US?
I think there are really good use case, tools related to literature reviews, environmental scans, that is really good.

codes.name: Research Design and Question Formulation
codes.description: This code covers the use of AI to assist in the early stages of research, such as brainstorming research questions, refining study designs, or identifying potential weaknesses in proposals.
codes.semantic_definition: Applications of AI to 'poke holes' in research ideas, strengthen proposals, or help formulate better interview questions, acknowledging that human expertise remains critical.
example_quotes: I've also done things for proposal writing and taken my idea where I want to use a particular design and poke holes in this; What are the problems with this; how can I strengthen this?
I think that it's not the most consuming, but definitely the hardest is to find the right questions, as if have the designed the right protocol.
I'm not sure AI could do that. Maybe it could, but to me, as like we're the subject matter experts and sort of and really being able to think about what is it because it's not.

codes.name: Speaker Roles and Perspectives
codes.description: This code captures the different professional roles of the interviewees and how their specific expertise and responsibilities shape their views on AI, research methods, and their implementation within RAND.
codes.semantic_definition: Mentions of specific job titles, departments, or areas of expertise that influence a speaker's perspective on AI or research methods. This code is about *who* is speaking and *how* their role informs their statements.
example_quotes: I'm an associate operations researcher. My primary methods are quantitative, so I'm a optimizer. I do. A lot of modeling, simulation coding...
I'm actually a clinician and so I mostly consume research. I'm familiar with quantitative and qualitative methods, but I run big teams and people on my teams do that research...

I'm Lynn, Carolyn. I'm a senior economist at Rand. Most of my work is more quantitative. Either using existing data or collecting primary data to look at the either descriptively at inputs and outcomes, or to try to model. Cause and effect.

codes.name: Quantitative Researcher Perspective
codes.description: This code captures insights and concerns from speakers whose primary expertise lies in quantitative methods, including economists, operations researchers, and statisticians, regarding AI's impact on their work.
codes.semantic_definition: Statements from individuals identifying as economists, operations researchers, or those primarily using quantitative methods, discussing AI's role in data analysis, modeling, or statistical procedures.
example_quotes: I'm an associate operations researcher. My primary methods are quantitative, so I'm a optimizer. I do. A lot of modeling, simulation coding...
I'm Lynn, Carolyn. I'm a senior economist at Rand. Most of my work is more quantitative.
I'm a student at the grad school here and I do social network analysis and AI and data structuring type things.

codes.name: Qualitative Researcher Perspective
codes.description: This code captures insights and concerns from speakers whose primary expertise lies in qualitative methods, including those conducting interviews, focus groups, and historical analysis, regarding AI's impact on their work.
codes.semantic_definition: Statements from individuals identifying as policy researchers, political scientists, or those primarily using qualitative methods, discussing AI's role in interviews, text analysis, or data collection.
example_quotes: I'm Christina Holland sky. I'm a policy researcher. I have been working mostly in primarily in national security, in information warfare on crude systems, great power competition, more strategy related projects. I am using qualitative methods only recently and I've been drawn. Into interview work quite a lot.

My research is mostly on Interstate conflict and competition. A lot of deterrence, escalation management issues relating to equally between China and Russia work across the DoD FRECS pretty broadly. Methods wise do a lot of qualitative. Stuff interviews, focus groups, lit review, historical archival analysis, stuff sort of thing.
Probably my most common methodology is, is qualitative interviewing, though I've done social media analytics and surveys and things like that.

codes.name: Mixed Methods Researcher Perspective
codes.description: This code captures insights from speakers who utilize both qualitative and quantitative methods, reflecting on AI's potential across diverse research approaches.
codes.semantic_definition: Statements from individuals explicitly mentioning the use of both qualitative and quantitative methods, and their views on AI's applicability to their mixed-methods work.
example_quotes: So I actually do quantitative and qualitative analysis. A lot of my healthcare projects are focused on qualitative data collection. And then when we finish collecting the data, I have done some quantitative analysis on the results that we got.

In terms of methods, some kind of across the board subclan data, some qualitative qualitative would be mostly things like interviewing workshops, things of that nature, quantitative. Modeling type things.
But I've also done a decent amount of quantitative stuff. Statistical analysis, forecasting large data models, that sort of thing. So a little bit all over the place.

codes.name: Research Consumer or Manager Perspective
codes.description: This code captures insights from speakers who primarily consume research or manage large research teams, focusing on AI's utility for project oversight, efficiency, and the broader impact of research.
codes.semantic_definition: Statements from individuals who describe their role as consuming research, running large teams, or focusing on project management, and their observations on AI's potential benefits or challenges in these areas.
example_quotes: Hi I'm actually a clinician and so I mostly consume research. I'm familiar with quantitative and qualitative methods, but I run big teams and people on my teams do that research, and then I put it together and think about. How the clinical implications...
So I would completely agree with Lynn and what I think is would be really I think of it as project management and I think of it as figuring out what are the critical paths right.

codes.name: Entity Relationships
codes.description: This code identifies and describes the interactions, comparisons, and competitive dynamics between RAND and other organizations (e.g., government, private AI companies) or internal RAND departments as they relate to AI and research.
codes.semantic_definition: Any discussion comparing RAND to external entities, or describing internal RAND organizational structures and their interactions concerning AI or research methods.
example_quotes: My sense is the Army thinks our competitors are integrating AI wholistically. Secretary of the Army wants Palantir and not RAND. Palantir would be doing things on our data.

I feel like this is the type of thing we are not read in enough on it. The way AI adoption happens is stovepipped and a lot of the discussion is in GER, so in QA process, I will like, if someone utilized RANDCHAT (to write their report) to make sure that is not happening.
Like if you would like a war gaming expert, you would come to Rand.

codes.name: RAND vs. External Competitors
codes.description: This code highlights the competitive landscape where RAND operates, specifically in relation to private AI companies or other research organizations, and the perceived threat or opportunity AI presents in this context.
codes.semantic_definition: Comparisons between RAND and other entities (e.g., Palantir, other research organizations) regarding AI adoption, capabilities, or market position.
example_quotes: My sense is the Army thinks our competitors are integrating AI wholistically. Secretary of the Army wants Palantir and not RAND. Palantir would be doing things on our data. So we think there is a risk to our research being utilized opportunistically by AI company to get ahead and to put us out of business.
If we could forecast more accurately in the outset then we could have more accurate recommendations than competitors.

codes.name: Internal RAND Collaboration and Structure
codes.description: This code captures discussions about how different departments, centers, or individual researchers within RAND interact, collaborate, or are structured in ways that affect AI adoption and methodological development.
codes.semantic_definition: Mentions of RAND's internal organizational units (e.g., Methods Centers, departments), internal initiatives, or the dynamics of collaboration among RAND researchers regarding AI or methods.
example_quotes: Need to be company wide ai initiatives that every unit and division are asked to participate in.
I view the Center as a convener of researchers who have expertise in causal inference techniques.
I think oftentimes we don't have these types of conversations with diverse groups and the whole point of this is to bring a diverse group of people together.

analytic_question: What are the key themes, speaker roles, and entity relationships in AI implementation interviews?
